title: First-Class Letter Delivery
question_text:
The U.S. Postal Service recently released data on the number of days it takes for a first-class letter to reach its destination, as shown in the table below.
What are the mean and standard deviation for the number of days it takes for a first-class letter to reach its destination?
What are the mean and standard deviation for the number of days it takes for a first-class letter to reach its destination?
solution:
The mean of a probability distribution is found by using the following formula:

μ=the summation of each xi⋅pi term

μ=(1)(0.42)+(2)(0.27)+(3)(0.3)+(4)(0.01)=1.9

This means that in the long run, the average number of days that it takes a first-class letter to reach its destination is 1.9 days. Notice that this is not one of the actual values of the random variable, but it still is the value of the mean, or expected value. Do NOT round expected value.

The standard deviation is a bit more difficult to calculate. Use the formula first for the variance of a random variable:

Variance=the summation of (xi−μ)2⋅pi

σ2=(1−1.9)2⋅0.42+(2−1.9)2⋅0.27+(3−1.9)2⋅0.3+(4−1.9)2⋅0.01

σ2=0.75

The standard deviation is the square root of the variance, so the standard deviation for this probability distribution is
